I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $75,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) to Far East Horizon Limited (FEH) for the Far East 
Horizon Health Care Finance in Rural Areas for COVID-19 Response Project in the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project entails the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing longer-tenor financing 
to FEH for lease finance offered through its wholly owned subsidiary, International Far Eastern 
Leasing Co., Limited (IFEL), to rural county public hospitals in the PRC. The loan will meet FEH’s 
funding  requirements  for  longer-term  funding,  support  health  care  finance  to  underserved 
segments, improve readiness for managing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks, and 
support gender-based violence (GBV) victims. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  The health sector overview. Rapid economic development since the 1980s has been 
accompanied by a significant rise in health care expenditures in the PRC. However, such 
expenditures continue to lag global averages, and the health sector still faces significant resource 
constraints. The PRC’s health care expenditure per capita was $688 in 2018 (calculated based 
on purchasing power parity)1, well below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and 
Development  average  of  $3,994.2 Since  2000,  the  PRC  has  made  significant  progress  in 
developing its national medical insurance system. By the end of 2019, basic medical insurance 
had more than 1.35 billion recipients nationwide, representing a coverage rate of more than 95%.3 
With the Rural Cooperative Medical System covering more than 95% of the rural population and 
reimbursing about 80% of medical expenditures, improvement of local county hospitals becomes 
the key to improving rural health care standards. As of December 2019, there were about 16,175 
county-level hospitals, 36,000 town and township health centers, and 616,000 village clinics 
nationwide. However, further investment in health care infrastructure is required, especially in 
rural regions. There are still wide urban–rural disparities in access to health care and quality of 
health care services. In 2016, the annual health care expenditure per capita was CNY4,472 in 
urban areas compared with CNY1,846 in rural areas.4 As of 2018, the number of beds in medical 
and health institutions for every 10,000 people in urban areas was 87, while in rural areas it was 
46. As of 2018, there were 109 health care professionals and 51 registered nurses for every 
10,000 people in urban areas, while in rural areas there were 46 health care professionals and 
18 registered nurses for every 10,000 people.5 
 
4.  Financial Leasing industry. Hospitals often have difficulties accessing bank finance, as 
banks typically do not accept medical equipment and land (which is typically owned by the 
government) as collateral. Leasing provides a good solution, whereby hospitals can directly lease

medical equipment or use sale and leaseback of existing equipment to secure finance for 
additional investment. The PRC’s leasing industry has been growing rapidly since 2008, targeting 
this financing gap that traditional bank financing does not address. Despite rapid growth, the 
PRC’s financial leasing industry still needs further development. The lease penetration rate in the 
PRC was 1.90% in 2018, ranking 19th out of the top 50 global leasing markets.6 
 
5.  Impact of COVID-19 pandemic on the health sector. The COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan 
stretched the local health care system to the breaking point, with many hospitals overwhelmed by 
patients. The entire country was subsequently put under lockdown in varying degrees. COVID-19 
also had enormous indirect impacts on the health care system by reducing its ability to provide 
effective medical services to other patients, some with life-threatening diseases such as cancer, 
because of reduced capacity or suspension of treatment for non-COVID-19 patients in many large 
hospitals, and because of the general lockdown. While 4,746 people have died from COVID-19 
in the PRC as of 1 October 2020, probably more lives were lost because of the delay in receiving 
medical care for other conditions. To contain the outbreak, the government has identified a list of 
hospitals as “fever clinics” that receive patients with such symptoms and has designated a small 
number of hospitals per city as COVID-19 treatment hospitals. These COVID-19 treatment 
hospitals are mainly in urban areas, and not all rural counties have hospitals included on the list. 
After the major COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, the PRC has experienced several local outbreaks 
in Beijing, Heilongjiang, Liaoning, and Xinjiang provinces, which were successfully brought under 
control by strict targeted lockdowns, extensive testing, and effective contact tracing. However, the 
risk of further outbreaks persists. Therefore, it is important to continue to enhance the capacity of 
designated COVID-19 treatment hospitals, as well as those providing critical medical services to 
non-COVID-19 patients during the pandemic and particularly in underserved rural areas. 
 
6.  Gender  impacts.  While  the  PRC’s  growth  and  development  have  led  to  notable 
socioeconomic progress, gender inequality remains, including in the area of GBV.7 In 2010, 
24.7% of women aged 24–60 reported experiencing domestic violence in the 12 months prior.8  
The first law in the PRC to specifically target domestic violence was passed in 2015 and, despite 
considerable progress, there are still challenges to its effective implementation, such as a lack of 
awareness and capacity among frontline anti-domestic violence service providers, including 
health care providers.9 As a result of COVID-19 lockdowns, many women are confined with their 
abusers, with limited options for seeking help in confidence,10 leading to an increase of GBV 
incidents. 
 
7.  Rationale. ADB’s nonsovereign operations projects in the PRC’s finance sector have 
actively supported leasing, targeting diverse subsectors focusing on underdeveloped segments, 
including health care.11 The $75 million ADB loan disbursed to State Grid International Leasing

B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
8.  FEH started operations in 1991 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2011. 
FEH is rated BBB– by Standard & Poor’s.13  It is the third-largest financial leasing company (FLC) 
in the PRC by assets with total assets of CNY289.3 billion as of June 2020. Financial leasing, 
conducted through IFEL, is the core activity of FEH’s businesses.14 With operations covering 30 
provinces, financial leasing comprised 91% of FEH’s total interest-earning assets as of the end 
of June 2020, reaching CNY203 billion. FEH operates in health care, urban public utilities, culture 
and tourism (including education), engineering construction, machinery, chemicals and medicine, 
electronic information, livelihood consumption, and transport and logistics. FEH traditionally 
focuses on mid-tier clients with stable cash flows and good growth potential, offering them 
specialized and integrated services. In addition to financial leasing, FEH also has industrial 
operations, including (i) full-service operating leases where leased equipment is operated by FEH 
staff, which ensures efficient operation and maintenance; and (ii) investment and management of 
hospitals and schools. FEH has the largest equipment operating lease asset portfolio among 
FLCs in the PRC, and it has gradually scaled up investments in and management of hospitals 
and schools since 2014. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
13.  ADB will provide a senior unsecured loan to FEH of up to $75 million (or its yuan 
equivalent) with a tenor of up to 5 years.  
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  Use of proceeds. FEH, through its financial leasing subsidiary IFEL, will use the proceeds 
of the ADB loan to finance the lease or purchase of modern medical equipment19 through direct

C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
17.  Provide long-term stable finance. The majority of FEH’s bank borrowings are shorter 
term (para. 15). For long-term finance, the company issues bonds, which are capped by the 
annual  foreign  bond  issuance  quota  granted by  the  government,  and  registration  with  the 
government is required for each issuance. The pandemic further reduced the availability of long-
term finance from commercial sources. Compared to the first half of 2019, in the first half of 2020 
the total amount of bond issuances in the PRC with tenors of 3–5 years dropped by 27.45%, while 
bond issuances with tenors of up to 3 years increased by 30.68%.22 Long-term funding from ADB 
will help support the company’s longer-tenor lease products for health care (the majority of health 
care lease finance provided by IFEL has a tenor of 5 years), and increase the company’s capacity 
to expand its rural health care leasing operations. 
 
18.  Strengthen rural health care and pandemic resilience through leasing. Leasing is an 
effective modality for equipment finance, particularly for borrowers that lack eligible collateral. As 
noted, however, the leasing sector in the PRC remains underdeveloped. By supporting medical 
equipment leasing during the pandemic, ADB helps promote leasing as an effective financing tool 
that will enable rural public hospitals to fill their funding gap, enhance their medical capacity and 
improve readiness for managing COVID-19 outbreaks.

frontline health care providers hampers effective implementation of the PRC’s domestic violence

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
20.  Impacts. The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) rural medical and health 
service system improved; (ii) capabilities regarding emergency medical assistance, and disease 
prevention and control strengthened; and (iii) financial leasing industry developed. The project 
will improve county-level hospitals’ access to finance, and thus enhance the rural health care 
system’s  capacity  and  reduce  the  urban–rural  area  disparity  in  health  care  standards.  By 
providing longer-tenor finance to a major FLC, ADB will be contributing to the development of the 
PRC’s underdeveloped leasing sector.24 
 
21.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: health care capacity in rural 
counties strengthened, including improved readiness for managing COVID-19 outbreaks and 
supporting GBV victims. 
 
22.  Outputs. The project will have three outputs: (i) FEH’s health care leasing operations in 
rural counties expanded. FEH, through IFEL, will disburse $75 million (or its yuan equivalent) of 
lease finance to public hospitals in rural counties, of which at least $45 million will be provided to 
finance leases to designated COVID-19 treatment hospitals in rural counties. (ii) Support for GBV 
victims enhanced. FEH will promote public awareness and provide appropriate staff training to 
enhance support for GBV victims in its operated hospitals. (iii) Gender equality of FEH’s work 
environment enhanced. FEH will introduce an anti-sexual harassment policy and related training 
for its own staff. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
23.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project supports ADB’s 
Strategy  2030  operational  priority  5  (promoting  rural  development  and  food  security)  and 
operational priority 2 (accelerating progress in gender equality).25 By financing hospitals in rural 
counties, the project will help address inequalities in health care access in the PRC. By promoting 
private sector finance for public health care investment, ADB will help develop a suitable solution

24.  Consistency with the sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is in

The project builds on previous ADB support for the PRC’s leasing industry and health sector 
(para. 7). By supporting the health sector and businesses negatively affected by the pandemic, 
the project is aligned with ADB’s strategy for COVID-19 response under private sector operations. 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
25.  ADB has categorized the project in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009).29 
 
26.  Category FI (treated as C). FEH’s business activities using ADB’s proceeds will have 
minimal or no adverse environmental or climate change impacts and are unlikely to entail impacts 
on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The loan’s potential environmental and 
social (E&S) impacts, and its risks associated with FEH’s use of proceeds and capacity for E&S 
management, have been assessed based on performance in the implementation of the active 
ADB loan to FEH to support financial leasing of medical equipment in underdeveloped regions 
(footnote 12). The E&S measures and the institutional capacity to manage the project’s E&S 
impacts are deemed adequate. The project will only finance the lease or purchase of medical 
equipment through direct lease or sale and leaseback transactions. ADB funds will not be used 
to finance any construction or expansion activities that may lead to adverse environmental, 
involuntary resettlement, or indigenous peoples impacts. 
 
27.  FEH has an organizational structure for E&S management involving a top manager with 
a dedicated E&S team. It has developed a corporate management system framework for health, 
environment, and safety (HES) that operates under an HES manual developed based on the 
National Occupational Health and Safety Management Requirements GB/T28001-2001 and 
National Standards of Environmental Management Systems GB/T 24001-2004. The HES manual 
specifies procedures, requirements, and responsibilities covering leadership, risk assessment 
and control, legal compliance, organizational structure and responsibilities, resource distribution, 
capacity building, document control, operational control, contractor and supplier management, 
emergency preparedness, noncompliance and remediation, incident management, internal audit, 
and management review. Regular monitoring is carried out by asset managers who often have 
relevant  industry  compliance  experience  and  are  aware  of  HES  issues.  An  HES  training 
mechanism under FEH’s human resources department is in place. FEH publishes a corporate

28.  FEH  will  (i)  apply  ADB's  prohibited  investment  activities  list;  (ii)  exclude  activities 
categorized  as  A  and B  on  environment,  involuntary resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples 
impacts; (iii) ensure that the uses of ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
and abide by applicable national laws and regulations, including national labor laws, pursuant to 
ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001); and (iv) take measures to comply with internationally 
recognized core labor standards. FEH will confirm this in its annual report on compliance towards 
safeguards and applicable national laws and regulations. 
 
29.  Effective gender mainstreaming. FEH has achieved gender balance in staffing with 
women representing 51% of its 17,903 staff. The company has a policy of performance-based 
remuneration with an explicit clause of nondiscrimination based on gender. The company does 
not have an anti-sexual harassment policy. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), FEH has committed to incorporate measures to promote gender equality and/or women’s 
empowerment in its business activities. Key features of the gender action plan are as follows: 
(i) hospitals operated by FEH develop a process to work with law enforcement agencies to 
support GBV victims; (ii) hospitals operated by FEH promote public awareness on GBV support 
services for victims, including hotlines; (iii) FEH develops guidelines for hospital staff on how to 
support GBV victims; (iv) FEH conducts annual training to frontline staff in hospitals operated by 
FEH on how to identify and support GBV victims; and (v) FEH develops and implements an anti-
sexual harassment policy and trains staff both at induction and annually. FEH will submit periodic 
reports on the implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
30.  FEH was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
D.  Assurances 
 
31.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),30 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to FEH. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$75,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Far East Horizon 
Limited for the Far East Horizon Health Care Finance in Rural Areas for COVID-19 Response

metadata.Subject:
The project will provide longer-tenor financing to Far East Horizon Limited (FEH) for lease finance offered through its wholly owned subsidiary, International Far Eastern Leasing Co., Limited (IFEL), to rural county public hospitals in the People's Republic of China. The loan will meet FEH’s funding requirements for longer-term funding, support health care finance to underserved segments, improve readiness for managing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreaks, and support gender-based violence (GBV) victims.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated October 2020 is provided for the ADB project 54366-001 in the People's Republic of China.
